Not sure how many folks are doing this, but figured I’d share in case it would help your mixing workflow. 

I have my sessions set up with busses that allow for me to be able to print my main, heated ref and all of my alt prints at once.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I’ve been thinking a lot lately (after seeing the very talented Matt Huber’s mix template) about how I fundamentally hate what the modern mix deliverables requirements have done to how songs sound and more importantly feel these days. 

How you can clearly hear the music and the vocals were mixed separately, tracked separately, considered separately; Where a record sounds like a drum bus and an instro bus and a bv bus and a vocal bus, because someone somewhere down the line might need to make edits. Great for commerce, kinda a bummer for creativity and art. 

Sometimes a heavier hand with processing on the final mixbus can help those things gel a bit, to blur those lines. When I got to work with Zedd he said he basically mixes and masters all his own stuff because if you were to take off his mixbus schmutz the whole thing falls apart, and no one else can put it back together to his satisfaction. But he’s basically involved in every inch of his mix from writing to programming to mixing. 

What exactly are we doing anymore, what are we trying to achieve with the mix. The how is easy. What’s the why?

Old man yells at cloud.

author: Slow Hand
content:
This is tangentially related, but I think Gullfoss can be a helpful guide-rail for new/intermediate mixers, but it requires commitment to the premise to be effective. I'll explain:

When used on the Master Buss, Gullfoss can provide a positive improvement in mixes. The trouble comes if you have a habit of solo'ing your tracks or groups when you mix. When you solo, Gullfoss will adjust it's curve to optimize for the solo'ed sound. This can lead mixers to make changes to the solo'ed elements that are even *less* effectual than if they'd been solo'ing on a non-Gullfoss buss. It can lead inexperienced mixers to chase their tail even more if they aren't careful.

So I'll summarize it like this: To gain benefit from Gullfoss you have to commit to mixing without solo'ing (generally a good practice), otherwise it will continually re-adjust itself and exacerbate the tail-chasing that comes from mixing and making moves while solo'ed.

author: cian riordan
content: I've definitely been reconing with this more and more. I thought I established my mixer 'brand' as someone who builds things from the ground up, a fresh start on the song. Clearly there's been an evolution to things coming in more fully baked, but recently I had a whole record where the sessions came in fully baked. They sounded very good, were incredibly intricate in how they were layered, and the bus processing was such a massive part of the sound that anytime I tried to build up something my own way, it wasn't even in the same ballpark. I ended up buying every plugin on the clients master bus and 'resigned' myself to small tweaks. I totally changed my approach and it became incredibly liberating... to know that something is already so close to being finished, but spending my time throughtfully making small changes that amounted to a 10-15% gain.

author: Matt Huber
content:
Allllllll the time. I feel like sometimes I can get to the finish line with it, other times, it makes it utterly impossible to get it beyond 85% done. 

I find that most folks slap on a multiband comp because they like the tonal shape of it. 

So, one thing that I find very helpful in situations like this is to think about these mix busses as contributing 2 different things - dynamics and tonality, and recreate those things in a less convoluted way. 

Practical example (from a mix last week): 

Capture the EQ shape of the entire chain using Ozone EQ match, then bring things up to a similar level using a single limiter. 

In the case of the song I was mixing, I instantly had the vibe / shape of the producer mix buss without the limitations of mixing into layers of highly interactive processing.

author: cian riordan
content:
So for all the mixing nerds here, thought you mind find this interesting. For the past 6 months or so I've embraced the idea of having an analog mix buss. I've always strayed away from it in lieu of keeping things fluid for easy recalls. However, since I've been doing 100% of my mixing in this studio and this gear probably isn't goin anywhere, I've been more comfortable leaning on a hardware chain with (what I think are) great results. 

First, I'm going into an old UTA Unfairchild. This was the first model that came out with the 6BC8 tubes instead of the current 6386 tubes. I always preferred the older model and was lucky to snatch one when Barefoot kicked the bucket. I'm not actually doing any compression, I've just got gain at unity and signal passing through. The second stage is a pair of UTA MPEQ-1's. I *thought* that I was doing a high shelf boost starting at 8.3k going into a LPF @ 22k. 

I've really, really been enjoying the sound of this. I notice a little midrange clarity from the unfairchild and I find the additive high end on the buss is much more musical than boosting individual elements.

author: Eric Martin
content:
Just from the hour of watching JC mix yesterday I understand a little better how things get “loud” in his mixing. He uses peak limiters and clippers everywhere, so nothing has a chance of peaking out from where he placed it. That’s in effect trimming all the Attack of an instrument but not really messing with the decay sustain or release because with a peak limiter it’s acting so fast that you can use it to manipulate a sound without it drastically changing the other aspects of it ADSR in synth world works the same in all audio. A clipper does the manipulation for “saturation” to get the desired grit that we might have gotten in yesteryear from things like tubes tape and transformers.

I think that it’s likely a smart fast and easy way to get a result like JC is looking for where it’s loud and sounds open still. Because you can’t really hear the peak limiting like you can hear a compressor doing 4:1 compression. Also know JC has a 1k “handicap” as he calls it on his mix bus, pulling out a few db and he is using the spectral shaper from 1-6k to tame harshness on the mix bus. (Don’t do this just because he does) These are things he’s added because it helps him get to his desired result faster, and when you mix one or two songs a day everyday for years you’re going to develop “tricks” or “handicaps” or whatever you want to call them to help you get to your desired result.

Learn everything you can about mixing if that’s what you want to do, and use only the things you try that YOU like, not because someone else makes work you like, your mileage may vary

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I’ve moved away from housekeeping passes like that. I called it “eating my vegetables”, where I’d assist myself - tuning, de-clicking etc ideally with a gap before sitting down to mix proper. 

Now, unless it’s a real train wreck I usually prefer to jump straight into the mix and see what comes out in the wash. 

I sometimes found myself being a hammer and everything looking like a nail, maybe tuning too tightly and needing to relax it once the mix had been built up. Or like how mastering can reveal issues that weren’t spotted in the mix, when the vocal chain and mixbus high shelf are in, clicks would be revealed that I wouldn’t have heard before, so I l’d wind up having to do another pass anyway.

Maybe most importantly though, by the time I got to mixing I could wind up already too familiar with the song and it’s nice to come at it fresh like clean socks.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Wish I’d Known This: Reaper (free infinite fully functional evaluation copy/£60 commercial) has amazing rendering workflows that allow you to batch export stems through mixbus processing (or other routing). 

Lots of people here probably much more advanced in Reaper than me, but I saved hours with it this week. Did a batch track bounce from Tools (select desired tracks, right click track title and choose bounce), then dropped these into Reaper and let it render the lot through my mixbus chain. 

Took 18 mins to do 30-40 stems (for a 10 minute song), and I could fuck off and make dinner rather than sitting in front of Tools doing Solo > Cmd Alt B like a jerkoff

author: Ross Fortune
content:
(Incoming self-indulgent ramble that I’ll probably regret on sending - but there’s some sense in it, and I’ve been typing for so long now that I can’t not post it)
 
For sure. Sometimes the mountain analogy doesn’t quite click with me because I feel it infers challenge, met with triumph. 

But I never feel like I’ve triumphed! And the challenges don’t feel specific enough to be “met”, per se. And even if they were, nobody is marking this stuff empirically out of ten (hear me out @BatMeckley 👀).

I produced + mixed a single early on in my bedroom (Rokit 5s, baby!) that attained certain undeniable metrics of success, but listening back, it’s so clear that it did so *in spite* of my (in)competence as a mixer. It still *feels* great, but sonically it’s all over the shop. I’ve since wandered the great valley of intuition-knowledge-intuition, and the only really crucial thing I’ve picked up is that if it *feels* great, the rest is largely (obvs take that lightly) inconsequential. I know this is not a novel thought, especially recently here. But anyway…

Another reason for my certainty about this is that there are so many records I listened to in my teens (pre any recording/mixing/critical listening experience etc) that *felt* amazing and blew my mind then, and still do now - even though now I can step back and hear the abrasive guitars, out of tune everything, etc etc.

All this to say that the reason I don’t ever feel like I’ve triumphed / bested a climb is that in 1/2/5 years from now, I’m going to listen back on my work from today and cringe at the over brightness, the congestion, the brickwall filter ringing at 732Hz 👀, the mixbus compression folding too hard on that downbeat…

author: sethearnest
content:
The Way to Export All Tracks from Logic to Equal the Exact Mix that the Artist/Producer Left Off From™

1. Any busses you want printed need to be showing as "tracks" in the Arrange window. You can do this from your Mix Window by selecting all busses/auxes you want to print, right-click, choose "Create Track", and now those Busses/Auxes will show up in your Arrange Window. Do this for any and all effects, parallel busses, etc etc

2. ignore step 2

3. Turn on your Cycle range you want to export (yellow bar across the top like Marv said) and select all tracks you want to export

4. File --> Export --> All Tracks as Audio Files

5. If next dialog box doesn't have options showing, smash that Options Button and choose various options
  a. Range: Export Cycle Range Only
  b. Uncheck "Bypass Effects Plug-ins" if you want their processing
  b. Include Audio Tail and Include Volume/Pan Automation selected
  c. Normalize Off

6. I suggest making an AES-Standardly-named New Folder and exporting into that 

7. Export that bad boy

This will ensure you can import into your Industry Standard DAW exactly where they left off, minus the mix bus processing. 

If they're sharing effects (e.g. guitar and vocal both going to a verb), and you want them both wet but also separate, then they'll need bounce those separately or dup the verb send/return (in which case their Valhalla Vintage Verb will be 12dB too loud b/c they'll forget to turn off their 2bus processing when they bounce it separately)

author: Maxim
content:
I’d say when all efforts have been exhausted to try and get stems you’ve only got a few options depending on how “badly” the beat is mixed. But generally my approach might look something like this: First pull down the volume by a bunch. Then usually you’ll want to add in some transients back again. I like Spiff for this to taste. Then sometimes Master Rebalance by Ozone can be a life saver. Especially if say the balance of some instruments are clashing with the vocal or the 808/bass is too loud in relation to everything else. Essentially I’m “unlimiting the beat”. 

Then together with the vocal in the mix I’ll try to shape the beat around the vocal with some subtle (usually reductive) eq moves. Something like dynamically sidechaining a bell on the hihat frequencies to the vocal can help a lot. Or I might also play with Spectral Shape. Some people get good results with sidechaining the vocal as a whole with trackspacer or soothe. Then if I’m missing some super lows or excitement I might throw a Pultec/Bax-type EQ or Spectre on it. 

So ultimately I’m creating as much space as possible and give myself enough headroom to still do some typical mixbus moves.

To me this removes the need to do anything different on the mixbus. Even though it’s likely I won’t be able to push as hard.

author: ALXCPH
content: An important thing to remember about MB compressors is that you aren’t explicitly taking things out but rather re shaping the envelope of those frequencies. Which is what makes it a bit dangerous on the two buss as you won’t just be affecting the envelope of one sound. Not to be a purist at all but try and figure out what it is that it’s actually doing and how you can achieve something similar at the source. What you are describing sounds like your bass might be too loud. Or too long an envelope. There are other ways with much more control in which you can fix that issue. IMO.

author: chrissorem
content: Lots of good  ideas on the mix bus talk!  I think it can be easy to get in the weeds with the “Mix Buss”  I’ve found for myself that I will try these different techniques over the years for example,no mix buss treatment and only a limiter.  Then I tried the music/vocal buss thing. Then I tried only processing the groups and lighter on then mix buss processing.  What I learned is there is no right or wrong way to do anything  and it’s good to try different approaches out but if you feel you are fighting something it’s a good idea to check the processing and see if it’s tying your hands. The only way I know how to do this is gain match your inserts and turn them on and off.   I’ve mixed with the inflator and had good results,  and it’s also been horrible. I’ve mixed with Vulfcomp on the master (generally a horrible idea  but in certain cases it rules!) I even mixed with altiverb on the mix buss recently.  Good technique is  very important but sometimes I like mixing into something wildly colorful and it can take you to very interesting places sometimes you have to work harder for it but the end result can very unique

author: Slow Hand
content:
Maybe I'm alone here, but does anyone else dislike the sound of clippers? Especially on the master buss. I hear it all over contemporary records and just don't care for the aesthetic.

Maybe I'm doing it wrong, but it always results in things sounding mush-y or smeared. The only amount that I like is barely perceptible, at which point I find myself wondering why bother at all(?). Whenever I try put it on a mix I eventually A/B it later and find myself liking the un-clipped version.

The only reliable usage I've found is on percussion that's very transient and very noise-y. Like a hand clap. It helps me to get the absolute level down, while boosting the apparent loudness.

Don't get me wrong, I love distortion, but I'm not a fan of that particular flavor.

author: Eric Martin
content:
I think, again, it’s knowing the reason you’re using the tool, it’s mostly used when you want to accomplish something on the sides or in the mono signal when you can’t get to the track that needs the help, if your mixing, you should go to the track that needs the work first, not a M/S tool, M/S tools are designed for working on stereo tracks and shaping things because you CANT shape the original thing you want.

Example, the vocal is a little quiet in the mix, using a M/S tool to help bring the 1-2k of the vocal out in the mid without bringing out too much 1-2k of the cymbals and guitars on the sides because that balance was already where you wanted it. In this situation you can’t get to the vocal because you don’t have the track, BUT if you’re mixing, you can reach for the vocal and boost a narrow Q at 1500hz to accomplish the same task but in a cleaner way.

This is the type of reason I might reach for M/S, I don’t reach for M/S if guitars need to be brighter on the sides, I find the guitars on the sides in my mix, and make them brighter.

This is also the same reason to argue against multiple bus processing, because if the ability to use such a processor is there, we will use it, take away a bus and we have to work harder to get the mix done, but the end result can be much more effective, impactful, dynamic, and inspiring, but it takes longer and requires a lot more finesse.

author: JustinLeu
content: A few things I've found helpful is setting up my mix sessions with many points of control--- VCAs for all groups and then more specific (*All Music* *All Drums* *Kick/Snare* *All Vox* etc...) then a master fader controlling how hard I hit the 2bus. Starting with the biggest section of the song helps as well. I can then automate the other sections up or down *including the master fader feeding the 2bus*  As far as clipping/limiting on sources/busses I find it good to shape the sounds how I want (more heavy lifting) then the busses/2bus end up just glueing it together with a lighter touch. I think the 2bus doing too much of the lifting is where it can start to fall apart.

author: spectrummasters
content: If its any help, fwiw , imo It’s absolutely all about your gain structure and groups, and it’s kind of counter intuitive , you don’t want to be slamming anything ...just very careful db clipped here, db limited there ....across your buses . I have 6 group buses: . Kicks , 808/Bass , Drums , Music, Vox , FX and only clip by 1-2 db at the mixbus . Nothing clips by design or accident anywhere else .....for rnb/hip hop build your mix the Alex tumay / mixed by Ali way , get that 808 up first, on its own ....as loud as you want it , then build everything around it afterwards. Filtering is your friend. Have nothing in the low end but your bass. Overall I’d absolutely suggest watching Jon castelli mixing t Shine (he uses clipping well in there ) and mixed by Ali mixing YG , his mix balance and grouping is CHOICE. I say  somewhere between these two is the perfect rnb/hip hop mix lol . PS. I wouldn’t  do any of that edm/clip to zero stuff, it doesn’t work for anything other than serum madness.

author: aidanthillmann
content:
If you set up your Pro Tools template in a certain way, you can bounce stems super fast. I set up auxes and route stuff to them that will be a stem, so it’s part of the prep process (i.e. route Lead Vocal to Lead Vocal Aux, Keys 1 to Keys 1 Aux and so forth), so choose what you will for the song and split up however much you need to. Then I use sends (or you can multi-output) to respective audio tracks and name them (you can also include Instrumental, TV Mix and A Cappella as their own audio tracks). Record-enable all the audio tracks, record them down. Then use Soundflow to copy the mix buss plugins you need (Copy Track Data macro), copy them to all the audio tracks, then use Track Bounce to offline bounce all of the stems in one go, and it will include the plugins. Takes about 10-15min.

The only caveat with this is that you have to route any effects to the same aux, like Lead Vocal Verb has to go to Lead Vocal Aux and nowhere else, so you can’t share effects. But if you just create verbs for each thing as you go (or set up in your template) it’s no problem.

author: cian riordan

But for sun heavy pop, I send the low end out the other pipe so it’s not overly driving the compressor and/or distorting that low end. It’s been working well thus far

author: masteredbyjack
content:
You know, I've been thinking more about something like this. Almost always I would much rather refer people to a proper mixer...someone like @cian riordan  or @Adam Thein provides insane value IMO (also @Joshua Riley ). But I have, for whatever reason, recently been hit up more often about having me mix...and sometimes there isn't the budget to hire a proper mixer (I advocate for that up front whenever possible, even going so far as telling most people they should hire a mixer rather than me if they have to choose one).

Normally I just do the stereo master in those situations after saying my piece about the value of a mixer, but when people don't want to hire a mixer I have been considering just asking for the session (was chatting this with @Joshua Riley actually the other day). 

Often when I hear the "mix", I know if I just had the session I could improve it by way more than just having the stereo file...say just raise this here a half db put some color only on the vocal, tweak the mixbus, but for a lot of reasons I haven't asked for that yet. Maybe I will try this and see about the results!

Corollary is I find that stem "mastering" is honestly the worst of all the worlds, for me it would be either the standard stereo file master or give me the session. Which I would approach with a mastering mindset, accepting things for what they are and listening big picture.

Also I've come from producer/mixer land and being new to mastering in late 2022/2023 really...I am sorta less attached to what mastering "is" in the philosophical sense.

I often think of mastering as just making the song better (to my taste and ear) within the almost arbitrary restriction of just having the stereo file. Of course this ignores the mindset of approaching a full project! Which is a huge part of mastering. 

But as you stated, with how technology is evolving and the ease with which we can send stuff, may change. Excited to see where it goes!

author: cian riordan
content: This is why not leaning on the master bus compression too much is a good idea. Try subgrouping your instruments (drums, bass, guitars, synths, etc) and doing heavier compression on those sub-groups. That way if you turn up a synth it will only impact the compression scheme on that bus and not jam down the mix bus.

author: Matt Huber

This has made a massive difference for me productivity-wise. 

Like Chris, I also have things set up in my mix template to be able to build most non-PT sessions in 15 min or less.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
I have a full routing template including parallels, Inc ei get the files I'll organizettheninto their subgroups and everything gets routed. I just deleted the groups that don't end up with anything in them. I'm on S1 so it's easy to delete a lot of busses/channels in one go w a couple clicks. 

all my main sends are also setup but no actual plugins are loaded besides a clean gain plugin on my mixbus. I save my lost used chains/preset and I'll just drag them in as needed, I also delete the unused sends once I'm happy w the ones I got. as much as possible I duplicate the tracks and apply FX inline, makes exports so much easier. 

at this point I don't worry about getting my stem sound to be the same as the mix too much cause I try to get 90% if not more on the tracks themselves. my bus processing tends to be really really light. 

if a group works together I will do all edits I need to each element and just bounce the whole thing  as audio. I then disable and hide the old busses /channels, so I have a way to get back if ever needed.

author: jantrit
content:
I have a general template that has some mix bus/ master bus stuff that’s there but not turned on. Can work a little bit and then kick it into action and see what its gonna do. Then I’ll mix through it for the rest of the mix. Most of the template is just effects busses and print tracks for various pieces of outboard, something to make it super quick to paint without having to make and label everything from scratch each and every mix. Never usually having presets for individual elements but if I’m working on an album sometimes I’ll “build the sonic world” for one track and make a new template for that to import into the sessions moving forward as a bit of a time saver. Tweaks come track to track and record to record, always building new templates specific to the records I’m working on. 

If I’m mixing on the console that kinda becomes the template or preset, I’ll work on a track and build the mix, sit with the client and work revisions and then move onto the next track. Stemming the new track back over the same sorta map on the console and tweaking from there. 

I really try not to make anything to “one size fits all” because you can end up really fucking yourself but it can be nice to have little time savers. You just have to check that it’s making the situation better each and everytime you use them. If it’s not, don’t be precious start from scratch and you’ll get much better quicker results that way.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So my first big boy professional mix for another artist other than myself, I used busses like a summing mixer. I slapped defaulted Gem Dopamine on each bus for “analogue vibe” and went about mixing. 

The mix turned out dope, but not because the analogue simulacrum. The busses forced me to pay attention to gain-staging and overall headroom. But I didn’t learn that until later. Now I don’t try to simulate analogue summing, and I use just the Master Buss to figure out gain staging, but the proper principals I learned doing an “improper” thing have stuck with me. 

All that’s to say- mix in mono, reference, use busses… but pay attention to what’s working and why. Chances are you can learn more and faster if you’re not intent on proving only a certain outcome.

author: Adam Thein
content:
Hey great question!  Even with “include return and master effects” checked in the export settings in Live, your tracks won’t 1:1 with dynamics processing or non linear processing (saturation) without using external side-chain routing.

I’d have a discussion with your mixer about if they’d like you to remove your mix bus or if they’d like it baked into each track/stem you are printing.  If it’s the latter, you can create sidechain source tracks to feed plugins that allow for an external sidechain input to keep it closer to 1:1 (still likely not fully accurate with the nonlinearities in some analog modeled plugins).

This is a pretty tough thing to type out but if we can find a few minutes today where our time overlaps I’m down to hop on a VC and show my workaround for this situation in Ableton.

author: JakeTB
content:
Here’s the long-winded human version. We’re still on this learning journey so happy for any pushback or insight

For the most part, our group felt the tradeoffs of very subtle multiband often outweigh the benefits, since just putting those crossovers in the signal makes a bigger difference than, say, a dB of control.

We felt more liberal use of multiband can add an aggression and excitement that is very familiar and unique, and prefer treating it as a sweetener or energizer over the whole mix more than trying to control problem areas that could be addressed on tracks.

In the signal chain, its position can drastically effect how other tools behave. Up front, it can help a bus compressor or saturation device behave more predictably, but may mush things too much. Near the end, it allows those devices to play a more colorful role but may cause weird behavior when using fast, “transparent” limiters afterward. I like it first right now, most of our group like it near the end.

The hallmark signs of overuse for us were mixes that sound overly strident or when a vocal becomes inconsistent tonally from section to section as density changes.

Tools-wise, the group unanimously preferred minimum phase tools over linear phase or dynamic phase. OTT is a starting point, ear training to recognize that color. Once you hear it at 15-20%, you won’t be able to unhear it on many pop records. After ingraining that color, ML4000 and C4 both have their own flavors that can do a thing while offering tweakability when needed.

author: Slow Hand

I like the concept, but I wouldn't ever do it on the master buss because it constricts absolutely everything - not to mention potentially introducing phase-y distortions across the entire mix.

If I'm going to narrow that frequency range I'd do it only on the elements that are calling out to be narrowed in that range. Usually with EQ to darken the panned elements. My master buss ends up being *very* minimal and open to keep me from tying my hands at the end stage.

Then again, I'm also not Luca or Frank. If it works for *them*, cool!

yeah ive had it since it came out, same with soothe1 and all similar tools, @Joel "Roomie" Berghult was right. I tend to buy plugins to save time when projects come in. 

In the order I'd range these kind of tools mentioned here:

1. soothe
2. speccraft
3. reso and all others

If you have soothe, you're good imo. 

I liked this one (speccraft) because it gave me more control when I needed to chase a more targeted frequency without affecting the rest (i.e vocals, bass gtr, etc), stuff like that, but I use these kind of tools sparingly. cymbals, egtrs cabs, things like that, almost never on the mixbus because IMHO (don't shoot me), soothe-like tools, affect too much of the signal - suppressing resonances/frequencies "killing the depth" because of the pushing down of reverbs, delays, etc. That is not to say I never use it, there are times for everything, and every tool has its place but yeah. There are people who use it that way and still get GREAT results.
As much as I want to simplify my workflow, 90% of the job is audio janitorial, I go back to simple eq, compression, fader...

I saw another comment asking about Spiff > I don't know if anybody wanted my input on that but nevertheless - I like it sometimes on drums after tape-sims where it kills too much of the transients if I need to drive it more for *reasons* but the sound is lovely (i.e country), bit of spiff after and get best of borth worlds.

author: Josh Bowman
content:
For rock and folk music I generally just do subgroups like drums, bass, guitars, leads, bvs, lvs. For pop oriented songs generally more split out/ kick, snr, toms, hats, cymbals, fx, different synths split out etc. i just use soundflow scripts that solo and bounce what I tell it to and run it at night or at lunch. Freezing tracks first can make it go way faster. As for mixbuss, I take off my final limiter (or turn down the input, however the song was sent to mastering)… I’m usually not compressing the buss hard enough for it to matter. Sometimes the sum of the stems ends up sounding better than the mix! Generally people are using them for their MD to create a live show, or for dance remixes etc. For sync most people seem happy with instrumental and accapella in my experience so far?  Also if your trying to key your mix buss compressor from a printed mix, freezing most of the session first (besides fx etc and aux tracks) seems to help the side chain feel pretty close to what the mix was. I don’t bother with it though most of the time as I’m doing a couple db at most on the buss comp.

Edit: one other idea I’ve messed with pre soundflow, is, if your just doing subgroups and have the routing setup, save your mixbuss as a track preset and when your ready to print recall it on all your masters and commit the tracks. It works for me unless im using too much uad etc.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Got a question for my Audio DSP nerds: Does convolution of two audio signals introduce phase shift?

Convolution is most often used for reverbs, where phase shift is acceptable. But what if you convolved your audio signal with a fixed EQ curve that is 1 sample in duration?

As we all know, using a normal EQ imparts phase shift around those frequency bands, and an EQ curve with *lots* of bands, is likely to be a big, smeary, mess that distorts your phase relationships.

What if you took a big complicated EQ curve (like the type that you'd see on a Sonarworks correction curve), sampled that, and then used it with a convolver plugin to re-apply that same complex filter to your mix buss? Would this method sidestep the phase shift that you get from using traditional EQ bands?

author: Slow Hand
content:
Convolution is a strange technique to describe in a way that is intuitive to understand. But here goes:

In convolution you have two audio signals, your *input signal* and your *impulse response*. The simplest description of what convolution does is that it multiplies the *input* signal by the *impulse* signal and what it spits out is a new audio signal that includes only the frequencies and amplitude values that both signals have in common.

Practically speaking, what this means is that when you convolve an *input* (let's say, a full frequency drum kit recording) with your *impulse* (let's say a 5 ms burst of white noise that was hi-passed at 500 Hz). What you end up with is a drum recording that sounds like it was hi-passed at 500 Hz.

Think of it like how a vocoder works (which isn't that different). Your vocoder might combine a full-frequency synthesizer patch (input) with the frequency contours and time content of your voice (impulse/carrier). But if your voice doesn't have 100 Hz in it then we never hear the 100 Hz from the synth patch because the input and carrier/"impulse" don't share that frequency. What you hear is what both signals have in common. If your voice has a huge peak at 1.5k, then the synth patch is going to be accentuated in that same way.

So. What I'm saying is that if I have a complex EQ curve (ala Sonarworks corrective EQ) that I use as my *impulse response* and convolve it with, say, the output of my stereo buss, will it impart that frequency curve onto my mix *without* the phase shift that you'd get from a traditional FIR or IIR filter (aka traditional EQs)?

In short, I don't know because it's hard to search for the answer online. But I'm throwing a hail mary in case we've got any DSP nerds in the forum.

I leave all 2bus processing except I’ll duplicate the final limiter, disengage the original limiter with mix settings, take the input gain down to 0dB on the duplicated limiter for stems.

That way most of the sauce is there, the stems have more headroom, but any stray peaks are still gonna catch if they are present without input gain. 

Also means I can add a limiter with identical input gain to the stems and get my mix pretty in tact.

author: Rollmottle
content:
the case is the same digital or analog. it's a helpful tool to keep your gain staging in check. the key is what you calibrate the meter to and where you place it. 

it seems particularly useful on making sure you're hitting known processing chain inputs in their sweet spot. put the meter before any bus processing chain and calibrate the meter to its sweet spot. now you know quickly when you're hitting (or not hitting) the spot where you know it can do the thing in the way you expect it to do the thing. the other really useful one is post bus processing. set the meter on a bus output calibrated to a target level, now you know how gain decisions within the bus are or are not getting you where you want to be. for those working in templates and mixing into known bus processing chains, it seems like it would take a lot of the guess work out of gain staging decisions. it's a very broad stroke tool, but helps me very quickly make decisions on what level something needs to be juiced up or down to. just takes a little upfront work.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
specifically since I know you're in S1. if you have everything at a good balance I'd just select all the channels and bring the input gain down by 6 or however is needed to get you the headroom you want on the mix/master bus.  on the input mostly cause I'm assuming you have the waveforms at a good level of visibility at this point. 

I used to do the -18 thing but I stopped. felt like I was losing a lot of time and in most cases didn't make much of a difference. if it's not hitting where it needs to for some analog emu plugin I just gainstage within the the Plugins or, use the input or sometimes add a mixtool (utility) to make ABing easier. 

also in S1 you can bring down the inputs on all your busses before it hits they got to the master so you don't have to change each channel again and still get that headroom. 

as far as whether it's hogwash I don't think so. but i def coulent make it work. not for the type of music I was/am doing for the most part anyway.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Honestly have considered it, but I would normally just tell them what I think, if there should be changes and not charge them for a consult or something. 

Or ideally send them your way (I have actually tried sending some literally to you haha, but the few times they didn't bite on it) -- I think the way of listening as a mixer is just different to what I have been working on. @Nomograph Mastering has referred to this before I think and I find it's true.

A few times in a situation like that, a producer has sent me their entire mix bus plus the mix without it...and just bypassing half of the stuff does the trick almost immediately. The standard wild stuff going on...huge amounts of gold clip, all the new ozone bells and whistles, etc etc. Which aren't inherently bad but in my monitoring I can normally just get rid of it and use a simple EQ or something -- and I'm talking huge improvements. I think it's just down to a fresh perspective and great monitoring.

I'm not sure what to make of it honestly, I don't plan on changing how I operate, the move is always to get artists and producers to great mixers IMO whenever possible, and I love the team aspect of that, I think the art is better for it.

author: Zach Hughes
content: I recently revisited a mix I initially did in 2021 for an as of yet unreleased project. A folk / rock / americana track. My OG mix had this really aggressive edge to it that I kinda liked but it also felt way too scooped in the low mids. I checked out my old session and turns out I had cranked a ton of 8khz on the mixbus (a move I haven't felt compelled to do since 2021). Related I've been really enjoying thick / dense / full bodied mixes that still have excitement / edge up top especially for vocals and I had previously struggled to achieve a similar 'heft' in my own mixes compared to what I was hearing. I think in the past I was too quick to zap low mid resonances in my vocals / guitars. So I've been experimenting cutting less down around 200hz-600hz and emphasizing more. But then I felt I was losing some of that edge / excitement by see-sawing too much with the low mids relative to up top. I've found cutting some 170hz clears much of that up for me (like oh hey there's my snare or more room for kick / bass), I achieve the thickness above in that 200-600hz range and balance that with the excitement around ~8khz. Pushing and pulling.

author: aidanthillmann
content: I’ve recently been practice mixing against my mentor, and mine have been sounding like a mid range mess, where his had better energy and impact with better space in the mid range for the vocal. I thought I was making things “clearer” by letting the music have a good amount of mid range to poke out, but really I was just covering up the vocal and making a mess, and leaving the low and high end lacking in energy. So my revelation has been to pay better attention to the space that the vocal needs and make sure I’m making the music fit in with the vocal. Also, for me, multiband compression (in tasteful amounts) on the mix buss has been helping both with mid range control and overall better energy.

author: cian riordan
content: Limiting, clipping, any sort of containment is useful at this stage. That way a big downbeat on the drums won't pull down the vocals, and vice versa. Also helps you tailor any sort of 'sweetening' type things for the program material -- ie, all of the electric guitars could use a little low mid boost and a little air up top.... but if you do that on the master, you fuck everything up. Just sort of a different way of thinking about staging your elements into the final mix bus. I find that with this method, the actual mix bus does less work and you get alot of the impact & loudness without many of the downsides.

author: iampedrorafael
content: Same situation here, I used to avoid the "reality check" at the beginning of the mix so I could move primarily by feel. But then I was consistently making macro EQ moves on the mix bus in order to match the references a bit more at the end of the mix (typical 2db presence boost, maybe some 200-300hz scoop). This was a real pain in the ass, cause naturally things change a bit at that point and it's not an effective way to handle the problem. So now I have a preset for MetricAB with 8 reference tracks ready to go that I listen for short periods of time, sometimes 5 seconds or so, just to keep my years calibrated to what "normal" feels like in a macro-level. The fact that I don't need to leave the DAW environment (changing the visuals as well) to open a streaming app with different stimulus makes it really convenient to just do the right thing and compare apples to apples. The band-isolation mode really helps me to compare how different frequency ranges are moving also

author: BatMeckley
content:
Definitely overcooked.
Don’t be afraid to kill all the plugins and start fresh with the knowledge now of what you don’t want to happen. The ozone exciter is often the culprit when I start to wince. 

Also, in a section like this where you’re going to really push up against the glass of the master bus, instead of pushing the brightness of the gtr have you considered temporarily dimming other elements? Sometimes I’ll put a c6 side chain on a few busses, and have it duck the them based on the feature element. Ie, often across the let’s bus or guitar bus I’ll have the vocals ducking specific harsh (or bloating) frequencies, just in certain sections of the song. Might be worth taking a look at.

author: Tristan
content: I’m going down a bit of an inter-DAW routing rabbit hole at the moment. Reason being it can be impossible to recreate people’s mix busses in ProTools. Passing a 2ch O/P into Ableton with AUX I/O surprisingly works quite well, and I had some luck with omnibus and loopback, but all in all noticeable latency is unavoidable. Anyone care to give me the shortcut before I do a million tests this week?

author: Tristan
content:
Yah ofc

Biggest challenge for mixing - at least in my world - I get a lot of sessions that have crazy mix bus chains. Printing stems through mix busses, especially if they’re elaborate and working hard, rarely add up the same. Best strategy so far is generate stems with mix bus chain bypassed, then we recreate 1:1 in ProTools. There are a handful of plugins that are DAW specific, especially in Ableton and FL, so recreating those is near impossible, and I usually just end up mixing in the DAW or printing a few basic stems to keep the vibe and then pop back into PT.

My dream and current work in progress for this scenario is:
- Get stems (mix bus bypassed) and session from producer 
- import stems into ProTools
- ensure all stems feed a master 2ch 
- route that 2ch ProTools out via AUX I/O, loopback, omnibus etc
- new track in Ableton that picks up the corresponding input from PT
- delete entire session except for mix bus processing and send out my interface

This does work, and sounds exactly how I’d hope - but the latency is only just tolerable because it you’re on the higher side of buffer sizes usually to avoid glitches

Ideally I’d route it back into ProTools so I can print back in easily, but there are a lot more glitches and often increased latency, so I just print a clean 2ch WAV and import it into Ableton when I need to print.

Hella annoying and elaborate, but it’s the gig. 

The only other thought is looking into internal Symphony mixer and seeing if that can somehow improve things. That’s next on the list.

author: Tristan
content: Yah I have connector, it’s super handy. The challenge is the moment another plugin or app is involved the latency goes up by default. This is working good enough for now. Just annoying I need to bounce PT then into Ableton to produce a file. But I’m already nearly done with a Soundflow script that’ll bounce the pre mix bus audio in PT, import into Ableton, bounce it, reimport it back into ProTools just like it was a bounce dialog so probably stop here for now

author: Slow Hand
content:
The first thing that comes to mind is that you may be pushing into your master buss limiter too hard. 

How much gain reduction is your limiter currently doing? If you're already pushing aggressively into your limiter and then you're boosting low end *into* it, it's going to keep turning it back down.

If that's what's happening, the answer would be to back off your limiter so that the low end doesn't get compressed.

author: GaspardMurph
content:
Here’s what I do regarding loudness : I try to make the client stems hit my stereo bus around where the red line is by the top of the Mute button (very unprofessional that I don’t know)  - so I usually trim my groups (I have a VCA in my template that controls my different instrument buses’ volume). Usually when getting hot stems it’s around -3 / -4db trim. Rarely I get stems too quiet and in these cases I usually clip gain all stems down. 

Then I usually have ozone vintage limiter on at -2.5db which will add a bit of loudness with the auto gain and then set the maximizer to +2dbs.

By the time I’m done doing my thing with bus processing, eqing etc… I’m usually in a good spot lufs wise and then it’s a matter of turning up or down either the makeup gain on my compressor or the output of the maximized

author: chadwahlbrink
content:
@bobby k @Josh Bowman @peterlabberton if you are interested, I have a script in my “CW Pro Tools Utilities” package called “Bounce in Batch” on the soundflow store. That script can open, bounce, close sessions (or alias files from multiple sessions dragged to a single folder)! It’s still evolving, but it’s pretty stable at the moment. 

This allows you to set up your sessions with 2bus processing in place. You name your session after the stem you are setting up, and if you have to stop, select the stems left to bounce in Finder, and you are good to go!

author: Eric Martin
content:
right, there was a spectral shaper on low mids on one of his buses, but then again on the mix bus it was doing the 1-6k.

I think from what I understand that JC is doing he is controlling the attack so it’s consistent, then using the transient shaper to make sure it’s the same for every hit. It is smart, and for his workflow it’s also fast and easy.

I use compressors a lot, but I’m also working in mostly indie rock with acoustic drums and bass guitars not 808’s and drum machines, which is a drastically different world. I also think I’m doing what most people don’t do and I don’t always love the artifacts of compression so I generally use slow attacks to maintain transients and fast releases to recover quickly (I adjust so that I get the fastest release before audible distortion)

BTW Bruce Swedien while he may have evangelized not using compression don’t underestimate that his greatest works were done to tape and even when you were conservative and didn’t hit tape hard, the transformers going into tape and out of and the tape as a medium itself would peak limit attack heavy instruments like drums

author: ehutton21
content: I use Lift on drum bus after the tip i got here, as well as in the mix-buss/mastering depending on what someone wants and i use ruby on mixbus as well. the top end on ruby is next level. i’ve stopped adding a lot of high end on the way in and i found that band passing the highs on vox for mixes with a nice boost on the overall mix bus is more pleasing across the board for everyone. vocal cuts through real well and everything has a natural shimmer. i boost 4-ish db at 16k and cut by like 4-6 ish at 28k like jon referenced a few times, but i’m mindful that it’s a digital emulation and it isn’t gonna sound infinitely smooth.

author: ehutton21
content:
i just realized that i believe we’re talking about two different plugins! im using lift 3, I believe diamond transient is the one with the ability to clip in the mid range. i don’t have transient, but after my experience with using these across my mixes I’m pretty set on adding it to my arsenal. diamond lift 3 sounds big and powerful on bus and mastering duties. there’s a certain heft it adds in the clipping department that my other tools don’t have, but it’s compression and eq moves are actually quite versatile—it can be just as powerful but also surprisingly… musical?

i like compressor mode 3, clipped mode 1, and i gain stage the bus/track so i can drive the input on the plug-in, compress 1-2 db, drive the makeup gain of the compressor into the clipper so i’m on the verge of hitting the overs, then i gain match the plug-in to desired level. maybe add a little saturation there too. it’s got a subtle feel but it’s 👌🏼

my experience with this has been incredible with it on drum bus, music bus (albeit i’m not clipping), and mix bus especially when i get to the stem stage of my work in ableton (i do some stem work in ableton after doing the heavy lifting stuff in protools). pure insanity. 

i’m pretty disappointed that even with my mac m1 studio, acustica plugins in protools aren’t really running for me. gonna have to troubleshoot that.

author: BillyC
content: I just import some VCAs, FX returns, mix bus, and print track. All other routing is only done as needed, because routing decisions are really about processing. And those decisions are hard to make until I’ve heard the song and can see what stems I have to work from. I’ve just gotten too many sessions from people where there is so much bussing and subgrouping going on that by the time the vocal gets to the mix bus, it is passed through 3 instances off gullfoss and 4 different compressors and there is zero life in it. It quickly gets out of control. I actually find minimal bussing to be a quicker workflow because I don’t have to follow a whole series of subgroups to know the entire processing chain on a given audio source when I’m trying to make a tweak, nor will that tweak affect any other element that is sitting just fine. That’s just my brain though.

author: Will Melones
content:
Damn you just gave me an idea. I mixed a score once with different PT track folders for each stem, and dedicated reverb/delay returns for each instrument group to keep things separated.

I could offline commit all of the folders at once, and after a couple minutes of rendering I had stems. And in film it’s very important that the stems match *exactly*. BUT there was no master buss processing, intentionally.

But if you were to take your master chain and put it on, say, the last 5 inserts of each folder, identically, and only use dynamics plugins with sidechain inputs, you could feed your mix buss input to the sidechain of all those plugins. Then create a mix group wherein the settings for inserts f-j are linked…

This would obviously be an ITB-restricted solution with a heavy processor load. And I’m not sure how you’d set it up in Reaper, but it’d probably be even better than in Pro Tools

author: BillyC
content: I do kinda fuck with this as a default approach, but not because it's "EQing your speakers". Managing contrast well in a mix generally makes for a more immersive feel (even in stereo), and you do lose a bit of contrast between elements with every bit of processing that's on the entire mix bus. So I tend to have better results addressing EQ inside the mix first rather than beginning the mix with some preset curve that is likely to work against me.

content:
I've been playing around with the new *Stabilizer* module in *Ozone 10* (which is similar to Gullfoss), and I dig it. It's not bad. I've been using it on my 2-buss for my last two mixes.

*However,* you have to be careful with it. If you solo an instrument/group/etc, it will adapt its curve to *those* instruments, meaning it's now optimizing it's EQ for the subgroup, which can misrepresent the moves that you need to be making.

I'm also realizing that printing stems is going to be problematic with that on a stereo buss because the *Stabilizer* is going to adapt it's curve to each solo'd channel (facepalm).

On second-thought, this might be best reserved as a mastering tool only, or else only lean on it *very* lightly and print your stems with it off.

Actually interested to hear people’s thoughts on Gullfoss on buses. author: spectrummasters
content: Along with others suggestions , I would advise some easy quick  tools to help you diagnose  . Izotope insight has a very good spectrograph that clearly reveals what’s happening down at 20-30 hz and how much energy is there . We ve also discussed izotope tonal balance here as well , but it’s really a very handy diagnostic when used to investigate where your low end energy is against a referenced track you like . Izotope Match eq is another tool that again allows you to compare and contrast what’s happening in your low end . I’ve also found the Shawn Everett trick mentioned here , useful for investigating low end (put a brick wall low pass filter on your mixbus and sweep it down to the 20-30hz with your subs on and see what that actually sounds and feels like . The other thing I find helpful is my gain staging and buses are set up so that I know how much gr and level should be arriving at each bus , so you soon know if you’re too hot just by looking at the comp / limiter . The last thing I’d say is know your speakers . I apply all this to myself because translation is my main point of focus right now . I forget where I heard it said , but I heard it said that the listener hears the inverse of what we the mixers hear .

author: CK
content: just gonna throw this out there...Try the God Particle as your only mix bus plugin.  Use all the sweet spot targets, and forget about how much it is limiting.  Focus on getting the EQ targets dialed in with your mix, and the input target not clipping..  This taught me SO much about loudness.  My mixes consistently hit -9rms and -9 lufs when I get them dialed with EQ, and I no longer get the "smushed" feeling I used to get when trying to get loud. The mix actually breathes and is loud AF. Then when I get the eq targets dialed in, I see where I am hitting large amounts of peaks over 3-4db on the limiter, and then I address those peaks at the source in different ways. The God Particle I truly think can be a teaching tool, as well as a great sounding mix bus tool. I am now using it less and experimenting with my own chains. But seriously, this may help you as it helped me. The GP does not suck and I will always have it in the bag as sometimes it is just the right sauce.

author: LAPhill
content:
I've stumbled upon a workflow that's working really well for me, but might be impossible for record folks. I'm deep into the mix on a score I'm finishing up, and I need to deliver stems to the client (it's a video game, and stems will turn on/off depending on various factors). Since I'm getting pretty wide splits from the mixer, I'm able to save him the hassle of my tweaky notes and once the sonics of the track are nailed down, he sends me stems and I can do my stupid "this flute phrase should be a bit louder," "this guitar is more important in the blend than the piano here," etc. It keeps the mixer focused on the big moves and I spare him an hour per-cue of my nitpickyness. 

We have a lot of trust, though. And I would imagine that the risk is too high that people will go in and completely fuck things up if you were delivering stems (not to mention the master bus processing factor)

author: Ross Fortune
content:
While we’re here though, I meant to ask the other day when I @Rollmottle (I think?) recommended a VU meter plugin.

Someone told me years ago about setting kick and bass levels using a VU meter on the mixbus. Something like… each should hit -6 separately, then hit -3 when they play together. Maybe an Andy Wallace thing? I can’t remember the details, and haven’t been able to find it discussed elsewhere.

Anyone know if this is a thing, and if so, what that thing is?

author: Rollmottle
content:
Twas me...VU meters are very useful tools because of their relative nature. If you know where the sweet spot of a compressor is on a drum bus for example, you can calibrate 0 on the VU meter to that sweetspot. then mixing into your compressor isn't such a guessing game every time (because you get the needle bouncing around 0, not too far under or not too far over). 

i use a digital one on the way out when i'm hitting my analog chain so everything goes out at the relative same level. i use an analog one on the way back in calibrated to a "safe" level and i know when it's coming back in ultra hot or i need a little extra gain to get it to the sweet spot. when you're monitoring stays at a consistent level, VU meters can help you judge relative relationships quite easily. i could see it being useful in the use case you described if you've calibrated the VU accordingly. say you want to generally hit -10 at the mixbus...calibrate a -10 signal to 0 on the VU. everything you then feed into the mixbus will show on the VU + or - where you want to end up.

author: Ross Fortune
content: That’s cool. Is the advantage of the VU over using say the built in metering in PT that you can calibrate 0 to a known sweet spot, rather than having the remember that it’s -6 on the drum bus, -10 on the mixbus etc?

author: GaspardMurph
content:
If anyone is interested, this is how I do stems:
1) once mix is approved I make a “master” session save as which removes all inactive plugins and inactive tracks
2) I make inactive all the tracks
3) make inactive all master bus plugins (I don’t think stems need to go through it)
4) only make active the tracks of the stem you want to do and offline bounce. I get a pretty big session done in 30/40m

author: Calvin Lauber
content: Rather than reroute eveything, create a “master” Aux, make the input of that whatever the input of your existing master fader is, choose a new output path, then make the input of your actual master fader that new output path. Lower the gain of the “master” aux as much as you want to get headroom into the master fader.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So think of mid vs side in terms of panning left right & center, and think of EQ as volume. 

If you’ve got a lot of low end information on the sides, and say it’s fighting with a mono bass track that’s supposed to be holding down the majority of the low end, you can eq the lows out of those panned tracks, or you can blanket turn all the lows down on the sides with a m/s eq on a buss, so that the L and R info is quieter. It’s basically a group volume ride for frequencies instead of tracks. You can also do this on individual stereo tracks if just panning isn’t granular enough. 

The why & when is mostly about taste. I tend to mix into a proQ3 setting that has the sides hi passed around 100 for the same reason I have a pultec boosting highs & lows on the master- it just ends up doing a lot of work for me.

It can become problematic if I’ve got big toms in a song and, after I’ve got a mix starting to cook I’ll toggle it on & off to see if I’m doing more harm than good. For the kind of music I mostly do, it works more often than not, but the one song I sent to Cian for mixing he basically blasted me for doing that. (In his own kind and gentle way.)

But m/s eq isn’t just for the master buss. You can think about it for any stereo track. Sometimes, I have an acoustic that’s carrying the whole song, but the fundamentals are fighting with the vocal, so I’ll turn the mid down at that frequency (or side chain that to the vocal if it feels anemic when the vocal is out.) that leaves the sides as big as you like cause it’s not fighting with my mono vocal.

author: peterlabberton
content: First thing is getting all the audio in there, then all those tracks get assigned to a "vALL MIX AUDIO" group so I can trim and control with the VCA below the final mix buss. Then I organize everything by groups/stems by dragging below the associated "x_BUSS" track. Then I assign to the correct buss ("B", for instance). Then—and this is why I start with this layout—I name the "x_PRINT" track as needed ("GTR_LD"). This way I don't have to have pre-named busses that may or may not make any sense for the mix; I can just quickly go through and name based on what's below the print track. THEN I split eveything out so it doesn't look like an insane cluster; the print tracks go in the "STEMS" folder, the buss tracks go in the "BUSSES" folder, and all the audio tracks go in either the "MUSIC" or "VOCALS" folder. I am increasingly rarely using aux sends on a global level, so the "FX" stuff at the bottom is just there to quickly pull in and assign to a buss as needed. Otherwise I'm dup-ing tracks and putting FX there, or just putting FX inline on the track—*gasp!* The first three tracks are just there so I can flip to them quickly on my S1 and listen to the ref, the mix, or the stems (barely used).

author: JustinLeu
content:
Clippers can be great on busses. Great on drums etc… I find Standard Clip to be super intuitive to use and you can visualize what is happening. (Probably helpful if you are trying to gain understanding)

On the mixbus it can be helpful before the limiter but most of the time I would introduce it towards the end of a mix if at all. I would try hard clipping or a more gentle knee and see if between that and a limiter I can get something better than limiting alone.

Keep in mind that any saturation plugin (tube/tape) on the mix bus is “clipping” (soft clipping) and I find that gain staging in to that type of processing is more friendly to mix in to rather than hard clipping.

author: James Cronier
content:
Standard Clip question for those who use it: 

Why is the soft clipping % slider adding so much gain? Am I missing something? 

When I use a clipper on tracks or mix bus, I always use it where the gain isn’t changed, and the threshold of the clipping just gets pushed down. Kclip, limitless, or Elysia Aphla comp clipper all allow this to be a one click operation regardless of soft knee settings.

When hard clipping, the clip fader Standard Clip behaves as expected, but as soon as I mess with the soft clipping the gain goes through the roof.

author: Josh Bowman
content:
Oooff feel your pain that’s rough. This happens to me from time to time, not always that extreme tho.

Generally my first move is to listen while bypassing each thing and trying to identify what it’s making better and what gets worse, then if I decide to try and keep some of them I’ll attempt to move some of those plugs off the main mix buss and back onto a subgroup or instrumental buss. But no matter what it ends up with me looping sections and rebuilding the mix to match the rough vibe before I get into the actual creative fun part of the mix.

I have one producer i work with often who mixes into a comp on his all vocal buss and it’s slow and hitting like 3-6 db compression. It totally bones me while mixing so I usually end up rebalancing all the vocals section by section to match his mix before I “start mixing”. 

Sometimes I’ll just work into their buss shit and bypass the stuff/bands of each of plug that are only hurting and not helping. 

Real can of worms tbh. 

Last week I ran into the vocal buss issue- luckily it was a comp w side chain input so I did try out the sidechain, I pre fader sent all the tracks feeding it while copying automation to that send, then used a master fader to match the buss sc level to the original comps gain reduction  and it worked well in that situation and untied my hands while saving me from a whole vocal rebalance session. First time that approach ever actually worked though for me tbh. If its a comp that drums are driving into i find the sc input doesnt end up feeling the same usually.

author: vostral
content: Hello guys! I'm mixing a Trap hiphop song that i've produced. At the moment, i'm exporting the stems for a mastering engineer and a question comes up to my mind: As i playback when mixing, i'm listening to my 65 tracks all going through the mixbuss (Slate MixBus - Maag MagnumK - Bx_digital - SPL IRON - ProQ3). So the sound i'm hearing is the outcome of all the tracks being processed by this chain, and especially, compressed by the IRON compressor. So If i bounce every single track/stem individually, will they be compressed? When printinting the stems like this they would hit the bus compressor or not? Any ideas?? Thanks in advance ^^

author: Adam Thein
content:
All good it’s a little tricky at first and just really difficult to explain typed out for me.

Same concept as using a sidechain input from a kick drum to duck the 808 - an external sidechain allows us to give the compressor something to listen to and apply the compression from that source to another source.  When the kick is fed to a compressor on your 808 channel - the compressor “listens” to the kick and applies the compression curve from the kick onto the bass.

So in your case of printing stems with a mix bus compressor - you want the SPL Iron plugin to “listen” to the entire mix as it heard it before but then apply that compression to one track at a time.

We can do this in Ableton with some clever workarounds, which would be a lot more efficient to show you on a video call on the server if you are free later.  Essentially you need to print a version of your song at each point in your mix bus chain where there are dynamics plugins (just before the Slate plugin, just before the Iron Compressor but after all the other plugins) and then send that audio to those corresponding plugins’ external sidechain inputs and then you can use the “include return and master effects” and get the result you are looking for

author: BoozleBAM
content: So, I kind of took things for a little detour, but: I was sitting in this guys studio one day listening to tons of different tracks on his playback. Then again multiple times on his website etc. etc. I noticed this phenomenon that after listening to his tracks I would lose interest after about 30 seconds. They would sound great at first - all the tape shit and analog gear and whatnot - but I just consistently lost interest in all his tracks for whatever reason. Couldn't listen to them all the way through... Ran into him at the bar and started talking with him about compression and what compressors he uses on what and blah, blah, blah. To my surprise he's a big fan of compression and uses a lot of them at different stages - I think mostly because he has them and he can. Told me about how he'll have one taking off some and then another taking off some and then the master bus taking off some... I know this is a common technique to have different compressors taking off little bits, and one I've started to employ in the box, but I've concluded that by the time his tracks hit the master they're already pretty "smooth" and that master just takes the last edge off them - That's why I lost interest in his songs. Not dynamic enough for my ears. The end. Also, the fact that he only uses one inch tape could have something to do with it. The End.

author: earwormfarmer
content:
I’ve also been loving the unfairchild plugin and it’s great on the mixbus imo. Recently have been using it for back-bus compression, a technique I heard Andrew Scheps talk about which is basically a copy of the mixbus minus drums. Mix bus stays uncompressed or less compressed. Back bus gets compressed more aggressively than I would do a mix bus. Blend that under the mix bus to taste. Really good for locking all the instrumentation together around vocals without dynamics getting pulled around by the drums. I think Andrew uses some kind of 1176 but the idea works with all kinds of compressors.

Mix bus and backbus both feed into a 2-bus where more processing may happen. Something like Pultec EQP1q, tape emultion, Pro L2? But I like to change things up!

author: JustinLeu
content:
You could achieve the same numerical amount either way (no HPF or with HPF), the threshold would be different....but the same amount of compression is possible. 

What would be VERY different is how the compressed signal "feels" 

Think about what would happen if you keyed (side-chained) your mixbus compressor with the bass guitar vs if you keyed the compressor with just the snare drum. Given the same attack/release settings the entire mix would move differently.

author: kalpipal
content: If you're talking heavy mix bus compression: if you can use an external side chain on your bus comp (and it isn't already being used), I'd create a sidechain bus and send every single relevant track/bus to it **pre-fader** at the track's approximate level (trying to get pre-fader send level to match post-fader so the sum total drives the comp the same way as it would in the mix.)

author: N
content:
I understand the perspective of (lufs don’t matter) however I want some consistency amongst my songs AND to be sufficiently loud compared to others.

I am competent of achieving very loud mixes however the introduction of artifacts bothers me. Usually I’m low passing with ISOL8 to listen for limiting/clipping clicks. These artifacts are unable to be heard unless I have a low pass filter active but I theorize that they, along with the extreme compression subconsciously degrade the listening experience by discretely assaulting your ears to the point of needing to take a break from listening. 

My music can be related sonically to clara la sans “another night” give or take more or less busy. (Keep in mind her stuff is cranked to the point of audible artifacts sitting around -7ish lufs integrated across the chorus).

I arrange the mix well and leave 1db of headroom for summing on individual instruments whilst they are loud enough for my target of -10 LUFi across the chorus, meaning my mix is actually 1db louder than -10 with space to sum on the pre master bus. Leaving headroom means I can introduce less artifacts at the cost of having to squeeze the dynamic range of individual instruments more than otherwise.

My issue is that If I want to aim for let’s say -8LUFSi across the chorus in a relatively clean way with minimal artifacts, I’m forced to squeeze the mix to -7.

I’d love to hear y’all thoughts on whether or not technically inaudible artifacts/distortion matter and whether or not it’s really worth for me to squeeze my mix 2db more in the name of competitive loudness?

Ps. Please bear with me as I am trying to figure this all out solo. Feel free to criticize my approach.
